title: If humans die, do they exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: First, please  forgive me, but I do not understand the reference to picking up a shovel or random acts. I fear I may be guilty of picking up a shovel here... If so I apologize It has taken several days to have the time to respond to this question; this is related to death itself. Last night I lay my hand on the very cold and firm face of a 94 year old loved one whose heart slowed to a stop at around four pm. It has been an intense time, these last ten days since hospice came in to ease the passing. Twenty one years older than I, he was someone for whom I felt admiration. I held and stroked his hands and head during some of those terrible times when his consciousness came forth in its confusion and fear. Throughout the nine month transition from semi-autonomous old guy -- to resident of a Veterans Administration nursing home -- to death, his struggles potentially foretold mine yet to come. Thus I was immersed in both empathy and self reflection, and wish to share some of this here. I do not believe in an afterlife. I understand the science of death, and assume that when my heart stops for good what I think of as "I" will no longer "be." But, it has been my experience that by seeing something as metaphor, I can gain some clarity. One recent learning was triggered by a blog post in reference to Thoreau's writings being carried on to Gandhi & Dr. King. That led me to a favorite author, Loren Eiseley, and his book The Man Who Saw Through Time. What I'm looking at here is the realization that the writings of Francis Bacon (the subject of the book) as described by Bacon as his hope for his writings, were as "ships on the sea of time." So I come to a (as always, tentatively held) conclusion that while we are alive and upon the sea of time, our words have the potential to be carried on into the future. So now we run smack into the concept of time, and the plot thickens. I have no interest in debating the absolute scientific reality of time. To me it seems a construct that we employ to understand the order in which things happen. Our human concept of time is microscopic from a cosmic perspective. At that juncture, I again turn to metaphor and a marvelous author Susan Howatch. She wrote a novel, Wheel of Fortune, in which a character with deep roots in her Celtic heritage, speaks these words: “There is no timetable for grief,” said Bronwin Morgan. “Grief isn’t a train which you catch at the station. Grief has its own time, and grief’s time is beyond time, and time itself... isn’t very important. It’s the English who think time is a straight line which can be divided up and labeled and parceled out in an orderly fashion, but time isn’t like that, time is a circle, time goes round and round like a wheel, and that’s why one hears echoes of the past continually -- it’s because the past is present; you don’t have to look back down the straight line, you just look across the circle, and there are the echoes of the past and the vision of the future, and they’re all present, all now, all forever.” Dale Zhao said:  But they do exist to those who know them and love them, and perhaps exist forever in their worlds.  --  I think this is what Susan Howatch speaks of in her book. She goes on to suggest that we will look at a still living person touched by the deceased and see within them characteristics, traits, etc. that are living on. This can often be a function of a love shared between them. This is for me true of my maternal grandfather; he is alive within me and there was truly a love connection. He leads me to the words of Michael Dixon who said:  I feel that I am eternal in a way that I don't understand. Understanding death is not important in this world. I feel love in this world, and I believe love is eternal and beyond death. Hughston Fetner said: ...but I do think there are ways humans exist after death. We exist after death in our writing.There are literally parts of us in our children. When Our bodies die they decompose and become nutrients in a way it is like reincarnation. I think those are the ways we exist after death. And from love to words. My Grandpa was a man of words. He was a linotype operator turning typed words into molten lead cast into solid words on their way to being printed. He wrote poetry and I have read his powerful anti-war poem The War God in public and those words carry on as ships upon the sea of time.

The answer is in two parts, like the question. The first is fact-based. The second is wishful-thinking. When a human being dies, as with any other animal, it finishes entirely. Humans are animals. Life exists only if there is brain function. Medical science can do wonders in keeping a body going long after that human is dead, but brain death is absolute and final. One of the most successful pieces of religious propaganda ever is the notion that there is a soul separate from the body and that it continues on in an 'afterlife'. This is very comforting for those who have lost someone close to them so in that respect it is a nice amelioration. However it bears no relation to the stark real world. If there was such a thing as a spiritual existence, it would have to physically reside somewhere other than in a body which has finished existing. As we understand now, the only existence that is possible is in the form of matter or energy. Spiritual entities are neither and cannot exist. Belief in the spiritual is a very enticing confusion of thoughts.

When humans die their physical bodies die but their stream of consciousness will continue to exist. They go from being aware of one reality to the next. I believe this because there are certain supernatural, spiritual realities that exist that can’t be explained with logic or science (i.e., premonitions, visions, intelligence, the unveiling of transcendental thoughts or ideas at specific periods of time in human history, inspirations, art, music, creative ability, love, good, evil, the incredible and unexplained realities that exist).

I do not know what happens after death. I personally do not believe in an afterlife, but I do think there are ways humans exist after death. We exist after death in our writing. It is amazing that Marcus Aurelius, The apostle Paul, and Anne Frank can still talk to people through the words they have written down. Also when have kids we pass on our genes. There are literally parts of us in our children. When Our bodies die they decompose and become nutrients in a way it is like reincarnation. I think those are the ways we exist after death.

Yes , they exist . Not in their physical bodies ofcourse , but the soul survives . And with the soul , survives the karmic account, the good and bad deeds . Also survive the impressions ( sanskaras ) on the soul . A combination of the karmic account ( ie. the positive and negatives ) and the deep rooted sanskaras( desires ) determine future birth . Thus the cycle continues until liberation ( moksha)

As a decomposing corpse or carcass, sure. As a pile of ashes if one decides to get cremated, sure. To claim that their conscious is still somehow intact after the physical deterioration of their brains and that this conscious has now become a so-called “soul”/”ghost”/”spirit” that is going to travel to some mythical “afterlife” and/or be reborn into an equally mythical “pastlife”, nope. “Souls”/”ghosts”/”spirits”/”afterlives”/”pastlives” don’t exist if that’s what you were alluding to. Death is eternally final. The End.

According to some Religions, the 'soul' inside human body came out then it considered as death.. So death is only to human body and not to your 'soul'.. According to Einstein, Energy can be neither created nor be destroyed. It can be changed from one form into another.. Combining Religions and Physics, human body is transforming into other thing(decomposing) and 'Soul' transforming into some other energy(atoms)..

Do clouds have an afterlife? Do computers go to silicon heaven? What happens to your car after outs recycled? If you think the answer to those questions are obvious, why isn't the answer to your question also obvious? After you die your pattern breaks down and the material it's made of is recycled by other organisms.

Yes, humans will always exist. When we die, our spirits (souls) separate from our bodies. They continue to live in a spirit realm until it is our time to be resurrected to a perfect and immortal body. Then our spirits and bodies will be resurrected, never to be separated again.

The soul exists after the bodies dies and decomposes. The soul lives on in another plane of existance. That is the afterlife. Whether we remain ther for all eternity or re-enter another body through reincarnation, I am still not sure. But the soul definitely lives on after the body dies. Of that I have seen proof enough to be certain.

Humans exist before they die and cease to exist after they die. End of the line, finito. The same thing happens with elephants, butterflies, fish, pine trees. Not sure if you were expecting something more profound.

exist - having objective reality or being. when you die, you are still matter in this universe. you are a ‘thing’, just like a chair or a tablecloth. eventually, though, your body breaks down and gets completely decomposed in the ground. at this point, you no longer exist.

I don't feel that it's possible that I won't exist after death or after dying will never have existed. I said I feel not I think on purpose. If I try to think this one through I will end up confused and frustrated and will come up empty-handed. Mental agility is not really helpful. I am not a religionist and I don't argue with atheists or philosophers. I feel that I am eternal in a way that I don't understand. Understanding death is not important in this world. I feel love in this world, and I believe love is eternal and beyond death.

In my view their bodies still exist till they decompose or are cremated. The individual atoms are still present but they they go into some other plant or animal or just into bacteria or the soil. There is no evidence that their consciousness persists after the brain dies, no soul in other words

After death described in your way, these people do not exist, and even never exist, to you. Actually, they do not exist to you even when they are alive. But they do exist to those who know them and love them, and perhaps exist forever in their worlds.

Well, so far none of the people answering here seem to have past life experiences they recall, nor pre-birth experiences. I DO have these recollections, so people don’t ‘get erased’. Literally nothing is erased, until you get up and out of this karmic hamster wheel. This is my second time seeing this life, as I was shown all of it ahead of time, before I was born. So, unlike others who have no direct experience of this, or imagine that no one does (like Jamy Stevan) they just don’t know what they are talking about. All the reason in the world doesn’t buy you anything if you don’t have any experience to back it up.

There is a quote that we die twice: First when our life ends and then when we are remembered for the last time. For example Albert Einstein’s life has ended but he still lives on today. We see him everywhere and discuss him daily. My uncle has died but his values and ideas he shared with me are still alive today :)

Depends on whether you take it into a biological or spiritual spectrum. Biologically, no- you are now dirt. Spiritually, yes- the biological outer shell dies but the soul lives on at a high frequency.
Death may just be an eternal psychedelic trip, at least I'd like to imagine so. There have been various studies relating NDE's and DMT trips. Its worth exploring.

People aren't erased when they die, they simply stop living. The fact that someone is not living today does not negate the fact that they were living in the past. The fact that no one remembers them does not negate the fact that they were living in the past.  We can't travel to yesterday, but yesterday still happened.
They still exist if their DNA is passed on.
When humans die, do they still exist?  No. When the human brain dies and the human body dies, the human being stops from existing. Fin.
In Islam, they do, in the sense of the soul surviving until the Day of Judgment, at which time the body will be recreated.
Do you think you exist or do something worthwhile which making your existance feel right now when you are not dead !!
Your star stuff is recycled. That does not go away. Your consciousness does not exist. It’ll be like it was before you were born. Remember?
When something disappeares can it be still seen? Off course not! When someone dies, he is nonexistent. Until he is resurrected.
The matter that once comprised them still exists. The human does not.
